name: tuba
definition: The tuba is the largest and lowest-pitched musical instrument in the brass family.
description:
Tuba is a large brass wind instrument that generates deep-pitched sounds. It has valves and wide conical bore.

The instrument has a conical bore, meaning the bore diameter increases as a function of the tubing length from the mouthpiece to the bell.

Like all brass instruments, sound is produced by vibrating or buzzing the lips into a large cupped mouthpiece.

It takes a lot of breath to play the tuba. It is one of the loudest instruments in the orchestra but can also play very quietly.

The tuba usually plays the bass, lowest sounding, part even though it can play relatively high as well.

An orchestra usually has a single tuba, though an additional tuba may be asked for.

The tuba is used in all sorts of music and can be found in orchestras, wind bands, brass bands, jazz groups, pop groups, brass ensembles and even in tuba quartets.

facts.name: Generally constructed of brass
facts.value: The tuba is generally constructed of brass, which is either unfinished, lacquered or electro-plated with nickel, gold or silver.

facts.name: Biggest instrument in its family
facts.value: The tuba is the biggest of all the brass musical instruments. The largest tuba has about 5.5 meters of tubes.

facts.name: Dates back to XIX-th century
facts.value: They are the newest part of the symphony orchestra, first showing up in the middle XIX-th century.

facts.name: Tuba is used in jazz
facts.value: The tuba has been used in jazz since the genre's inception. In the earliest years, bands often used a tuba for outdoor playing and a double bass for indoor performances.

facts.name: Valves for fine tuned sounds
facts.value: Because they are so big, some tubas have a compensating system. This means a fourth, fifth or sixth valve is used to make the instrument sound more in tune - especially the lowest notes.

facts.name: Hélicon
facts.value: When tuba is wrapped to surround the body for cavalry bands on horseback or marching, it is traditionally known as a hélicon.

facts.name: Used to reinforce the bass voices
facts.value: It serves as the bass of the orchestral brass section and it can reinforce the bass voices of the strings and woodwinds.

facts.name: Concert tuba resting in player's lap
facts.value: A tuba with its tubing wrapped for placing the instrument on the player's lap is usually called a concert tuba or simply a tuba.

facts.name: Word 'tuba' was used for trumpet
facts.value: The word tuba originally was the name of a straight-built Roman trumpet and was the medieval Latin word for trumpet.

facts.name: Recording tubas
facts.value: Tubas with the bell pointing forward instead of upward are often called recording tubas, because of their popularity in the early days of recorded music.
